The permutation test procedure has the 
greatest power when the the two 
distributions are in fact different. 
The draw back is that simulations
take a long time to run.

The welch's test has the best power
overall.

The pooled t test has greatest power 
when the spreads of the test statistic
is smaller than 1.

The lln method has the highest power 
when the means of the two distributions
are the same.











R OUTPUT:
> power.pool
             mu2=0 mu2=0.5  mu2=1  mu2=2
sigma2=0.25 0.2195  0.4641 0.8396 0.9996
sigma2=1    0.0990  0.2381 0.5757 0.9789
sigma2=2    0.0600  0.1033 0.2588 0.7181
sigma2=5    0.0498  0.0595 0.0821 0.1822
> power.lln
             mu2=0 mu2=0.5  mu2=1  mu2=2
sigma2=0.25 0.1605  0.3782 0.7696 0.9986
sigma2=1    0.1300  0.2793 0.6211 0.9824
sigma2=2    0.1190  0.1882 0.3899 0.8426
sigma2=5    0.1321  0.1484 0.1899 0.3477
> power.welch
             mu2=0 mu2=0.5  mu2=1  mu2=2
sigma2=0.25 0.1041  0.2861 0.6694 0.9931
sigma2=1    0.1025  0.2334 0.5585 0.9735
sigma2=2    0.0955  0.1566 0.3436 0.8071
sigma2=5    0.1020  0.1138 0.1527 0.2986
